drop.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to stop holding or carrying something so that it falls
drop.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He dropped his briefcase on a chair.
She screamed and dropped the torch.
drop.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to make something such as a bomb fall from a plane
drop.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: U.S. planes began dropping bombs on the city.
Supplies are being dropped for the refugees.
drop.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to fall suddenly onto the ground or into something
drop.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The apples are beginning to drop from the trees.
drop.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to lower yourself or part of your body suddenly
drop.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: She dropped her head back against the cushion.
He dropped down onto the floor and hid under the table.
drop.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to fall to a lower level or amount, especially a much lower level or amount
drop.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The number of deaths on the roads has dropped sharply.
Temperatures drop quite dramatically at night, so bring some warm clothing.
Their share of the market dropped to 50 percent this year.
drop.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to reduce the level or amount of something
drop.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: You might be able to get them to drop the price.
As soon as she saw the police car she dropped her speed.
drop.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to decide not to include someone or something
drop.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: His name was dropped from the list.
Taylor was bitterly disappointed to be dropped from the England side.
drop.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to stop doing something, discussing something, or continuing with something
drop.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The proposal was dropped after opposition from civil liberties groups.
You can’t expect me to drop everything (=completely stop doing whatever I am doing) whenever you’re in town.
Oh, drop the ‘Senator’ (=stop calling me ‘Senator’) – just call me Gordon.
Some time later, the matter was quietly dropped.
New evidence was presented to the court and the case was dropped.
Students are allowed to drop history in Year 9.
drop.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: To her relief, Julius dropped the subject.
Just drop it, will you? I don’t want to talk about it anymore.
‘What about the money?’ ‘We’ve agreed to let it drop (=we have agreed not to talk about it anymore).’
drop.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to take someone by car to a place and leave them there, especially on your way to another place
drop.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Just drop me here – I can walk the rest of the way.
She dropped Johnny at the school gates at about 8:30.
drop.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to take something to a place and leave it there
drop.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: I’ve got your books – I’ll drop them round to your place later.
drop.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to visit someone you know, usually without arranging a particular time
drop.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: I just dropped by to see how you were getting on.
The kids drop round and see her from time to time.
Jan dropped into the office this morning to tell me her news.
Why don’t you drop in for a drink one evening?
drop.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: if a path, land etc drops, it goes down suddenly, forming a steep slope
drop.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: The cliff dropped down over a hundred feet to the sea below.
On the left the ground drops away, giving a view over the rooftops.
drop.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to suddenly stop having a relationship with someone, especially a romantic relationship
drop.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: She dropped him as soon as she found out he had been seeing another woman.
drop.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 7: to stop doing something, discussing something, or continuing with something
drop.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Both men have been released and the charges have been dropped.
When my mother was sick, I just dropped everything and flew to be with her in Seattle.
The project was going to be too expensive so the idea was dropped.
The company has dropped its plan to build a hotel on the site.
Some banks have dropped their student loan scheme.
Students may choose to drop a subject in their second year.
He has finally dropped the pretence that he’s innocent.
drop.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a very small amount of liquid that falls in a round shape
drop.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: As the first drops of rain began to fall, Michael started to run.
A single drop of blood splashed onto the floor.
A drop of sweat ran down her forehead and into her eye.
drop.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a small amount of liquid that you drink, especially alcohol
drop.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: George hasn’t touched a drop (=drunk any alcohol) for years.
She likes to add a drop of brandy to her tea.
drop.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: I haven’t got a drop of sympathy for him.
drop.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a reduction in the amount, level, or number of something, especially a large or sudden one
drop.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The results showed a sharp drop in profits.
Manufacturers report a big drop in new orders.
drop.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a distance from a higher point down to the ground or to a lower point
drop.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: There was a steep drop on one side of the track.
There was an almost sheer (=vertical) drop to the valley below.
drop.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: an act of delivering something somewhere, for example by dropping it from a plane
drop.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: Air drops  (=from a plane) of food aid were made to the region yesterday.
My first drop of the day is usually somewhere in north London.
drop.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to fall to a lower level or amount
drop.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The dollar dropped against the Japanese yen today.
Second quarter earnings this year dropped to $157 million from $182 million.
drop.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to stop doing or planning something
drop.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Plans to expand the business have been quietly dropped.
She was persuaded to drop the harassment lawsuit.
drop.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to lose money in business, a game etc
drop.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to place words, a picture etc into a particular computer document with the mouse
drop.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Either drag and drop the page into a message or choose Send Page from under the File menu.
drop.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: if there is a drop in the amount, level, or number of something, it goes down or becomes less
drop.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Yesterday saw a sharp drop in stock prices.
The first quarter total shows a drop from the same quarter last year.
Business is expecting a drop in interest rates later this year.
The club has suffered a dramatic drop in profits.
